titleStmt.title: Letter from William F. Cody to Clarence L. Hinkle, May 5, 1904
titleStmt.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

notesStmt.note: Letter and envelope. Curtis L. Hinkle was clerk of the Wyoming State Land Board in Cheyenne and friend to WFC. "Tynan" likely refers to Thomas T. Tynan, State Superintendent of Public Instruction in Wyoming under Governor Deforest Richards [see p202, Bonner] and Mayor of Sheridan in 1914 and 1915. Governor of Wyoming from April 1903 through 1905 was Fenimore Chatterton (1860-1958). "Johnson" may refer to Clarence Thomas Johnston (1872-1970), Wyoming State Engineer, 1903-1911. Governor of Wyoming from April 1903 through 1905 was Fenimore Chatterton (1860-1958). BBWW performed in Portmadoc, Wales, on May 5, 1904.

bibl.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
bibl.title: Letter from William F. Cody to Clarence L. Hinkle

div1.p: Well I have been just too busy to write you. I am well started and doing much better than last season— And I look to make good money. I will in the fall moovemove to france will show Paris this winter and France next summer it means continouscontinuous hard work.2 But if I live to a good old age it means. I wont have to worry for money. And I feel better working. I must be busy at something And the show business is the surest money maker—
Please say to the GovenorGovernor if he wants me to do anything special Politically for him to let me know Or in any other way.3
Will be glad to hear from you. Remember me to Tynan— Johnson and all— 4

back.note: Note 1: Buffalo Bill's Wild West performed in Portmadoc, Wales, on May 5, 1904.
Note 2: Buffalo Bill's Wild West spent its entire 1904 season in the United Kingdom. The 1905 season was entirely in France, beginning with performances in Paris from April 2 to June 4.

Note 3: Fenimore Chatterton (1860-1958) was acting governor of Wyoming from April 1903 until January 1905. Chatterton served as Wyoming secretary of state from 1899 to 1907 and became acting governor on the death of Governor DeForest Richards (1846-1903). He served as acting governor until the inauguration of Bryant B. Brooks (1861-1944), who was elected to serve out the remainder of Richards' term.

Note 4: Thomas T. Tynan (1860-1925) was Wyoming's superintendent of public instruction from 1899 to 1907. By state law, the superintendent was a member of the state board of land commissioners. Tynan later served as mayor of Sheridan, Wyoming, from 1914 to 1915. "Johnson" is likely Clarence T. Johnston (1872-1970), who was Wyoming's state engineer from 1903 to 1911.

Note 5: According to Wyoming From Territorial Days to the Present, edited by Frances Birkhead Beard in 1933, Hinkle held an appointment as "inspector general, with the rank of colonel" (p.45) on the staff of Governor Bryant B. Brooks, who took office in 1905. Cody's use of the title "Colonel" in addressing Hinkle in 1904 may suggest that Hinkle held some honorary military title before Governor Brooks took office.
